title: Judgment, Discernment, and Obedience
objective: Understand Jesus' call to wise discernment, persistent prayer, and obedient action as the foundation for life.

required_passages.text: Judge not, that you be not judged. For with the judgment you pronounce you will be judged, and with the measure you use it will be measured to you. Why do you see the speck that is in your brother's eye, but do not notice the log that is in your own eye? Or how can you say to your brother, 'Let me take the speck out of your eye,' when there is the log in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the log out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to take the speck out of your brother's eye. Do not give dogs what is holy, and do not throw your pearls before pigs, lest they trample them underfoot and turn to attack you. Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you. For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks it will be opened. Or which one of you, if his son asks him for bread, will give him a stone? Or if he asks for a fish, will give him a serpent? If you then, who are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in heaven give good things to those who ask him! So whatever you wish that others would do to you, do also to them, for this is the Law and the Prophets. Enter by the narrow gate. For the gate is wide and the way is easy that leads to destruction, and those who enter by it are many. For the gate is narrow and the way is hard that leads to life, and those who find it are few. Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep's clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves. You will recognize them by their fruits. Are grapes gathered from thornbushes, or figs from thistles? So, every healthy tree bears good fruit, but the diseased tree bears bad fruit. A healthy tree cannot bear bad fruit, nor can a diseased tree bear good fruit. Every tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire. Thus you will recognize them by their fruits. Not everyone who says to me, 'Lord, Lord,' will enter the kingdom of heaven, but the one who does the will of my Father who is in heaven. On that day many will say to me, 'Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and cast out demons in your name, and do many mighty works in your name?' And then will I declare to them, 'I never knew you; depart from me, you workers of lawlessness.' Everyone then who hears these words of mine and does them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock. And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew and beat on that house, but it did not fall, because it had been founded on the rock. And everyone who hears these words of mine and does not do them will be like a foolish man who built his house on the sand. And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew and beat against that house, and it fell, and great was the fall of it. And when Jesus finished these sayings, the crowds were astonished at his teaching, for he was teaching them as one who had authority, and not as their scribes.

segments.audio_script: Welcome to lesson nine. Jesus concludes the Sermon on the Mount with warnings about judgment, false teachers, and empty profession. He calls for discernment and obedience, ending with the famous parable of two builders.

Listen to Matthew chapter 7, verses 1 through 29. Judge not, that you be not judged. For with the judgment you pronounce you will be judged. Why do you see the speck that is in your brother's eye, but do not notice the log that is in your own eye? Jesus addresses hypocritical judgment while calling for wise discernment. He encourages persistent prayer, knowing the Father gives good gifts. The Golden Rule summarizes the Law. Then come sobering warnings: the path is narrow, false prophets abound, and mere profession without obedience is worthless.

Jesus balances non-judgmental attitudes toward others with discernment about false teaching. Prayer is answered by a good Father. The narrow gate requires intentional choice against the crowd. False prophets are recognized by fruit, not claims. The final parable contrasts hearing with doing; only obedience provides a firm foundation when storms come.

Central themes include humility before judging others, God's generosity in prayer, the narrow way of discipleship, fruit as evidence of authenticity, and obedience as the foundation of life. Jesus teaches with unique authority, demanding response to His words.
Reflect on this: Are you building on rock or sand? What areas of your life show hearing without doing? How does the narrow gate challenge cultural Christianity that requires little commitment?

Jesus concludes His sermon with urgent calls to obedience. Hearing without doing leads to ruin. True disciples build on the rock of His words. Next, we'll see His miraculous authority. Excellent work today.
